Award.AwardTitle: Optimal sampling and recovery for multilinear signals and systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research involves the development and validation of a novel framework for signals and systems defined in dimensions greater than two. Such multilinear signals can be viewed as high dimensional data tensors, and the associated systems as multidimensional linear operators acting on this class of signals. These mathematical objects are ubiquitous in science and engineering and of growing practical importance. They arise in time varying tomographic problems such as medical imaging, hyperspectral remote sensing, and seismic data acquisition and processing for rapid exploration for oil and gas, to name but a few applications. More recently multilinear signals have become prominent in the context of data analytics for social networks, online big-data management, data visualization, predictive modeling for disease propagation and forecasting of complex events.

Effective multilinear computation and processing requires generalization of the traditional 2-D factorization methods to higher dimensions. To date, tensor factorization techniques are either optimal in terms of compactness of data or operator representation but NP-hard to evaluate, or on the other extreme computationally feasible but can be severely non-compact thereby loosing structural information. This adversely affects the efficiency in sampling (tensor data compression) and computational costs in recovery of multilinear data using regularized inversion algorithms. In this context, the investigators develop fundamentally new approaches for tensor decompositions, which, while being computationally feasible, are also provably compact. Specifically, the investigators will develop: Algorithms for handling large scale processing for multilinear signals and systems; Optimal sampling and recovery of multilinear data as non-trivial extension of the theory of compressive sensing; and Tensor representation based, regularized inversion models and algorithms for multilinear inverse problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the project and the research work comes from development of a novel way to compactly represent data that are multidimensional/multilinear in nature, such as video (2 spatial and a time dimension), seismic (4 source/receiver and fifth time dimension), cell phone call quality data (2 spatial, 1 carrier, 1 cell phone type and 1 time dimension), and 3-D Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) data. Such multidimensional data are referred to as tensors and the project investigates novel low-rank tensor factorizations of tensors as means for a compact representation. For many problems, compact representations equate to robust inference, and in this context, we develop algorithms for handling large-scale tensor data processing and prove the optimality of these algorithms within the proposed theoretical framework. The project also investigates tensor representation based, regularized inversion models and algorithms for multilinear inverse problems, in particular, the problems related to de-blurring. 


The broader impacts of the work can be found in the variety of applications that the PIs have considered and have successfully shown the utility of the technical approach undertaken. These are (a) Seismic data completion from missing traces, (b) Robust deconvolution, (c) Unsupervised image clustering and anomaly detection, (d) Online completion and prediction, (e) Classification of hyperspectral images, (f) Prediction of cell phone call quality data from limited measurements, (g) Improving the indoor localization accuracy from RF fingerprinting measurements, (h) De-noising MRI imaging data, and (i) de-noising using multidimensional dictionary learning. All these projects were carried out in collaboration with a number of academic and industrial research partners, thereby extending the project scope and impact across multiple disciplines and avenues.
